results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, especially RYGB and BPD, effectively treats decompensated T2D by improving insulin sensitivity and secretion. The small intestine plays a central role in glucose homeostasis, with BPD reversing insulin sensitivity to normal and RYGB increasing insulin secretion.
population_specificity: Patients with decompensated type two diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the arguments for and against bariatric surgery as a treatment for severe obesity in adolescents, focusing on its therapeutic outcomes, long-term effects, and patient selection.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed superior weight loss and resolution of comorbid diseases compared to other treatments, but long-term outcomes in adolescents are still emerging. Not all adolescents benefit equally, and reliable predictors of success are lacking.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify early post-operative variables predictive of later weight and psychosocial outcomes in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Early weight loss trajectory was the most consistent predictor of medium-term weight outcomes (≤24 months), but its relationship to long-term weight loss maintenance was uncertain. Early eating adaptation may be linked to later weight loss, but evidence for early adherence or psychosocial variables was lacking.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (studies from 1954 to 2016).
study_duration: Follow-up varied, with some studies extending to ≤24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of bile acids in health and disease, including their contribution to the beneficial effects of bariatric surgery on obesity, glycemic control, and recurrent Clostridium difficile infection.
results_summary: The study found that bile acid-stimulated intestinal mechanisms contribute to the positive outcomes of bariatric surgery, such as improved obesity management, glycemic control, and treatment of recurrent Clostridium difficile infection.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of bile acids and bariatric surgery effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine weight recovery challenges in obese patients after weight loss through lifestyle modification or bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that weight loss alters energy homeostasis, limiting further weight loss and promoting fat mass restoration in patients who had successfully lost weight. It highlights the clinical challenge of weight recovery and associated health problems.
population_specificity: Obese patients who lost weight through lifestyle modification or bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omentectomy in addition to gastric bypass surgery provides long-term metabolic benefits compared to gastric bypass alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in weight, BMI, body composition, or metabolic markers between patients who underwent omentectomy and those who did not after 5 years. The results align with previous short-term studies showing no metabolic benefits from omentectomy.
population_specificity: 49 obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of bariatric surgery on oral drug disposition, particularly anticoagulants, and assess the safety and efficacy of anticoagulation therapy post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence on therapeutic anticoagulation post-bariatric surgery, recommending warfarin with monitoring over direct oral anticoagulants due to insufficient data on their safety and efficacy in this population.
population_specificity: Patients who have undergone bariatric surgery requiring therapeutic anticoagulation.
interactions: Changes in drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, or elimination due to altered gastrointestinal tract anatomy post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative pain, surgical outcomes, weight loss, and aesthetical satisfaction between conventional multiport laparoscopy (LAP) and single-port (SP) approaches for sleeve gastrectomy in morbid obesity.
results_summary: The SP approach resulted in significantly less postoperative pain during movement on the first two days compared to LAP, with no differences in pain at rest, operative time, complications, or weight loss at 6 months. Higher aesthetical satisfaction was noted in the SP group.
population_specificity: Patients with a body mass index lower than 50 kg/m² suitable for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review factors affecting the gastrointestinal absorption of levothyroxine (LT4), including potential interactions with bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that the effects of bariatric surgery on LT4 absorption are poorly documented, implying insufficient data to draw conclusions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a specific study population)
interactions: None mentioned (bariatric surgery effects are noted as poorly documented)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare visceral and subcutaneous fat loss across different strategies, including bariatric surgery, diet and exercise, and weight-loss promoting agents.
results_summary: The study found that subcutaneous fat loss was greater than visceral fat loss when measured as area, volume, and weight, but not as thickness. However, the percent decrease of visceral fat was consistently greater than subcutaneous fat loss across all strategies, with no intervention preferentially targeting visceral fat.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 89 studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update gastroenterologists on endoscopic bariatric therapies (EBTs) and provide practice advice on incorporating them into clinical practice for obesity and metabolic disease management.
results_summary: The study found that EBTs are effective for weight loss and maintenance, particularly in patients unsuccessful with lifestyle interventions or as a bridge to traditional bariatric surgery. It emphasized the importance of structured programs, comprehensive patient evaluation, and long-term follow-up for optimal outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, including those with severe obesity needing a bridge to surgery or other weight-limited interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether therapeutic management should differ for patients after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) bariatric surgery by reviewing pharmacokinetic studies.
results_summary: Increased rates of oral drug absorption were predominantly observed, but drug exposure varied. The study suggests considering galenic formulation and BCS class to predict oral drug exposure outcomes post-RYGB and proposes a strategy for prescription guidance.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review vitamin D deficiencies in obese populations before and after bariatric surgery, summarize surgical options, and explore recommendations for preventing/treating deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that obese patients are at risk of vitamin D deficiency before surgery, and bariatric surgery exacerbates this due to malabsorption. The role of gut microbiome changes in vitamin D metabolism post-surgery remains unstudied.
population_specificity: Obese and severely obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters of rivaroxaban in bariatric surgery patients to assess its suitability for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery did not clinically alter the pharmacokinetics of rivaroxaban, and changes in pharmacodynamics supported its effectiveness for post-surgical anticoagulation.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy.
effective_dosage: 10 mg single oral dose 1 day prior to and 3 days after surgery.
study_duration: 4 days (1 day pre-surgery and 3 days post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the limitations of bariatric surgery for diabesity and explore medical management alternatives, particularly rational drug combinations.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery, while effective, has limited availability and potential complications. Medical management, especially combinations like GLP-1 receptor agonists and SGLT-2 inhibitors, shows promise but lacks sufficient RCT evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with diabesity (diabetes related to obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether deep neuromuscular block (NMB) improves surgical conditions during laparoscopic bariatric surgery compared to moderate NMB and whether it poses a risk for postoperative respiratory impairment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in surgical conditions or postoperative respiratory function between deep and moderate NMB groups. Postoperative pulmonary function was substantially impaired in both groups, regardless of the NMB regime.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Rocuronium bolus and infusion (deep NMB group: posttetanic count of 1-2; moderate NMB group: train-of-four count of 1-2).
study_duration: Duration of surgery (deep NMB: 61.3 ± 15.1 minutes; moderate NMB: 70.6 ± 20.8 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic data for optimizing antibiotic regimens, particularly cefazolin, for preventing and treating skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) in obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that a perioperative prophylactic cefazolin regimen of 2 g is reasonable for obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery, though data on MRSA-active antibiotics in this population is limited. Therapeutic drug monitoring is recommended for vancomycin and teicoplanin, while oxazolidinones, daptomycin, and lipoglycopeptides show supportive evidence for SSTI management.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery or cesarean delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity, heart failure, and the effects of intentional weight loss through bariatric surgery, particularly in the context of the "obesity paradox."
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery improved cardiac structure and function, despite the obesity paradox. Obesity was associated with higher complications in ventricular assist device therapy but did not significantly affect mortality or transplant waiting list outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and heart failure, including those undergoing advanced therapies like ventricular assist devices.

study_goal: To determine the effect of postoperative incentive spirometry (IS) on hypoxemia, arterial oxygen saturation (Sao2) level, and pulmonary complications after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Postoperative IS did not significantly affect hypoxemia frequency, Sao2 levels, or 30-day pulmonary complication rates compared to clinical observation alone. The study concluded that routine IS use is not recommended after bariatric surgery in its current implementation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (mean age 45.6 years; 77.7% female).
effective_dosage: IS use 10 times every hour while awake (control group).
study_duration: Postoperative monitoring at 6, 12, and 24 hours, with 30-day follow-up for complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the rate of appearance, progression, or regression of diabetic retinopathy in obese type 2 diabetes patients treated with bariatric surgery versus medical treatment.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery appeared to prevent new cases of diabetic retinopathy compared to medical treatment, but there was insufficient evidence to support its effect on progression or regression of existing retinopathy. Heterogeneity was not significant, and publication bias was absent.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare 5-year outcomes of adolescent bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) with conservative treatment in adolescents and adult surgical patients.
results_summary: Adolescents undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass showed substantial weight loss and improved comorbidities over 5 years, but required additional surgical interventions and had nutritional deficiencies. Conservative treatment led to weight gain, with a quarter opting for surgery within 5 years.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 13-18 with severe obesity (mean BMI 45.5 kg/m²) in Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the long-term (>5 years) outcomes of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in young adults who underwent the surgery during adolescence, focusing on BMI, comorbidities, micronutrient status, and safety.
results_summary: The study found that Roux-en-Y gastric bypass resulted in substantial and durable bodyweight reduction and cardiometabolic benefits for young adults, though long-term health maintenance required adherence to dietary supplements and management of micronutrient deficiencies.
population_specificity: Young adults aged 13-21 years with clinically severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term efficacy and safety of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) plus best medical treatment (BMT) versus BMT alone in improving microvascular outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and a BMI of 30-34.9 kg/m².
results_summary: The study is the first RCT comparing RYGB plus BMT versus BMT alone for T2DM patients with a BMI below 35 kg/m², but results are not yet available (pre-results stage).
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM and a BMI of 30-34.9 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of bariatric surgery in adolescents with severe obesity, focusing on weight loss and comorbidity improvement.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found effective in reducing excess weight and improving comorbidities in adolescents with severe obesity, though long-term efficacy and safety data remain limited.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and gastric bypass (GB) for metabolic control in morbidly obese patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that SG showed similar results to GB in terms of weight loss, metabolic syndrome resolution, and glycemic control after a 1-year follow-up. The results suggest comparable short-term efficacy between the two surgical techniques.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (BMI 44.3 ± 5.9 kg/m²) aged 18-65 years from a Middle Eastern cohort.
effective_dosage: Not specified (surgical procedures, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and systemic benefits of bariatric surgery as a treatment for obesity and its associated comorbidities.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improves obesity-associated mortality and comorbidities such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and depression. The mechanisms of weight loss include changes in hunger, satiety, and food preferences, extending beyond simple restriction and malabsorption.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity, particularly those in the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively estimate the mobilization of lipophilic persistent organic pollutants (POPs) into the bloodstream following weight loss induced by bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that blood concentrations of POPs increased by 2-4% per kilogram of weight loss and remained elevated for at least 12 months post-intervention, though the clinical significance of these elevated levels remains unclear. The benefits of weight loss still outweigh potential risks, but further research is needed to assess long-term health impacts.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (270 participants from 5 studies).
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, with POP levels still elevated 12 months after intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical data on the use of direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in patients who underwent major gastrointestinal resection or bypass, focusing on efficacy and safety.
results_summary: The study found that rivaroxaban was effective in patients with major distal intestinal resection, while dabigatran was not. There is uncertainty about the efficacy of rivaroxaban and dabigatran after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, and rivaroxaban is advised to be avoided in gastrectomy patients. Data on apixaban and edoxaban in this population are lacking.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent major gastrointestinal resection or bypass, including those with distal intestinal resection or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the predictive role of preoperative fasting C-peptide, HbA1c, FPG, and BMI levels on diabetes remission in patients with type 2 diabetes following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that higher preoperative fasting C-peptide levels were associated with increased diabetes remission, while higher HbA1c and FPG levels were linked to reduced remission odds. BMI showed no significant association with remission.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers discussed the rising prevalence of cobalamin deficiency in pregnancy due to increased obesity and bariatric surgery rates, but did not specifically study the safety or efficacy of bariatric surgery itself.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that low maternal cobalamin (potentially linked to bariatric surgery) may be associated with fetal growth retardation, insulin resistance, and excess adiposity, but no direct results on bariatric surgery outcomes are provided.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly those with obesity or post-bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate psychological and psychiatric traits in post-bariatric patients undergoing body-contouring surgery to highlight the correlation between psychiatry and obesity and improve patient outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that post-bariatric patients seeking plastic surgery exhibited higher rates of psychiatric conditions, including body dysmorphic disorder, major depression, anxiety disorders, impulsivity, binge eating, and body uneasiness compared to controls. The authors recommend preoperative psychological assessment to reduce non-compliance and improve results.
population_specificity: 36 post-bariatric patients seeking plastic surgery and 21 controls with similar clinical features but not seeking shape remodeling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the psychological distress associated with severe obesity and the effects of bariatric surgery on psychopathological profiles.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be a helpful treatment for morbidly obese patients, with long-term favorable results on their psychopathological profile. The study also noted inconsistent results regarding the effect of severe obesity on cognition.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with psychopathological comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in quality of life (QOL), body image, and general self-efficacy (GSE) in patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: QOL, body image, and GSE improved significantly within 6 months after surgery and remained stable at 24 months, with no significant differences based on gender, age, or type of operation. Mental QOL was influenced by body image and GSE.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery (laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy or laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the skeletal effects of bariatric surgery, focusing on nutrient malabsorption and the role of vitamin D in calcium transport.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, particularly Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), significantly reduces fractional calcium absorption despite optimized vitamin D levels and calcium intake. Animal studies confirmed lower calcium absorption post-RYGB, suggesting non-nutritional mechanisms may also play a role.
population_specificity: Humans and rats (animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a novel lipo-body lift technique for lower trunk reconstruction following massive weight loss after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no major complications, with minor complications in 40% of patients, linked to smoking status and liposuction volume. The technique was deemed less invasive than traditional methods, with excellent tissue conservation and minimal undermining.
population_specificity: 25 patients with massive weight loss (mean age 39.4 years, mean pre-body lift BMI 26.71 kg/m², average weight loss 56.6 kg).
study_duration: Average hospital stay 3.52 days, drainage duration 3.56 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness, safety, and mechanisms of endoscopic bariatric and metabolic therapies as less invasive alternatives to traditional bariatric surgery for obesity and related comorbidities.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is effective but comes with substantial cost, morbidity, and mortality, leading to low adoption rates among eligible patients. Endoscopic bariatric therapies are presented as a less invasive option with promising clinical trial data.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and related comorbid illnesses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the underlying mechanisms, epidemiology, and therapeutic strategies for metformin-associated gastrointestinal intolerance, including factors like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as one of the factors affecting metformin GI intolerance but does not provide specific results on its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus experiencing metformin-associated GI intolerance.

study_goal: The researchers were not directly studying bariatric surgery but mentioned it as a comparison for postoperative DUS screening practices.
results_summary: The study did not investigate bariatric surgery; it focused on the cost-effectiveness of routine DUS screening after endovenous ablation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing endovenous ablation of the great saphenous vein, not bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of GI hormones (ghrelin, CCK, GLP-1, and PYY(3-36)) in controlling eating, glycemia, and obesity, particularly in the context of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and other bariatric surgeries.
results_summary: The study found that while CCK is well-established in controlling eating in healthy-weight individuals, the roles of ghrelin, CCK, GLP-1, and PYY(3-36) in obese individuals and post-RYGB patients remain uncertain. Only GLP-1 clearly contributes to meal-related glycemia control, and local signaling may play a role, though methods to assess this are lacking.
population_specificity: Healthy-weight individuals, obese persons, and RYGB patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on biochemical, inflammatory, and oxidative stress parameters in morbidly obese patients, comparing surgical outcomes to clinical treatment.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced body weight, BMI, waist circumference, lipid profiles, glucose levels, oxidative stress markers, and inflammatory cytokines while increasing adiponectin levels. No significant changes were observed in the control group receiving clinical treatment.
population_specificity: 60 morbidly obese individuals (10 men, 50 women), including non-diabetic and diabetic patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (surgical intervention: Roux-en-Y bypass gastroplasty).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe sexual function and associated factors in adults with severe obesity before undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Before bariatric surgery, approximately one-third of women and one-quarter of men were not sexually active, and about half were dissatisfied with their sexual life. Older age, depressive symptoms, and antidepressant use were associated with poorer sexual function in both sexes.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (median BMI 46 kg/m², 79% female, median age 45 years) seeking bariatric surgery at ten U.S. clinical facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of newer technologies and techniques in bariatric surgery, focusing on their efficacy and potential for treating obesity at earlier stages.
results_summary: The abstract states that bariatric surgery is efficacious for obesity treatment but primarily in late stages, highlighting the need for less invasive methods for earlier intervention. It mentions newer technologies in clinical trials or recently approved by the FDA.
population_specificity: Clinically obese individuals, particularly those in late stages of obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of bariatric surgery in adolescents, focusing on weight loss, quality of life, and comorbidity reduction.
results_summary: The study found significant postsurgical weight loss, improved quality of life, and reduced comorbidities like hypertension and diabetes in adolescents. However, nutritional deficiencies and rare but serious complications like Wernicke encephalopathy were noted despite vitamin supplementation.
population_specificity: Adolescents undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality of life (QoL) outcomes for adults following bariatric and body contouring surgery, focusing on appearance, wellbeing, and functional improvements.
results_summary: The study found significant clinical improvements in appearance, wellbeing, and QoL, including body image satisfaction, self-esteem, and physical function. However, adverse events like wound healing problems and appearance-related distress were also reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 and older who underwent bariatric surgery and body contouring surgery.
study_duration: Outcomes were measured at less than two years, two to five years, and more than five years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the psychology and psychiatry resources and practices in French specialized obesity centers (CSOs) for bariatric surgery candidates.
results_summary: The study found significant differences and shortages in psychology/psychiatry resources across CSOs, with most professionals systematically meeting patients before surgery but fewer providing post-operative follow-up. Despite variations, all professionals conducted psychological assessments, and about 75% offered psychological follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients in 37 specialized obesity centers (CSOs) in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) plays a primary role in mediating hyperinsulinaemic hypoglycaemia in post-bariatric hypoglycaemia (PBH).
results_summary: GLP-1 receptor blockade prevented hypoglycaemia in all participants, normalised beta cell function, and reversed neuroglycopenic symptoms, indicating GLP-1's primary role in PBH. The intervention significantly reduced insulin secretion and improved glucose regulation compared to controls.
population_specificity: Eight participants with confirmed post-bariatric hypoglycaemia (PBH) and a cohort of BMI- and glucose-matched non-surgical controls (NSCs).
effective_dosage: Intravenous infusion of GLP-1 receptor antagonist Exendin (9-39) (Ex-9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight loss through bariatric surgery reduces the risk of new-onset atrial fibrillation in obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery reduced the risk of atrial fibrillation by 29% compared to usual care, with greater benefits observed in younger individuals and those with higher diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with sinus rhythm and no history of atrial fibrillation (n=4,021, with 2,000 in the surgery group and 2,021 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine trends, geographical variations, and factors influencing bariatric surgery and the choice of procedure in France.
results_summary: The study found that LSG was the most frequently performed procedure (57%), followed by RYGB (31%) and AGB (13%). Significant predictors for procedure choice included patient demographics, comorbidities, and healthcare access, with large nationwide variations observed.
population_specificity: 41,648 patients in France, predominantly female (82%), mean age 40 (±12) years, with 68% having a BMI ≥40 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate pharmacological strategies for obesity treatment, comparing them to bariatric surgery, and discuss the potential impact of new drugs in development.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for severe obesity, with its mechanisms inspiring new drug targets. However, long-term safety monitoring for new drugs is emphasized due to potential adverse events.
population_specificity: Severe obesity patients (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous electrostimulation combined with specific training in reducing breast ptosis and improving projection after bariatric surgery compared to training alone or no treatment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in breast ptosis, projection, and patient satisfaction in the group receiving electrostimulation combined with training compared to the other groups, with no significant differences between training alone and no treatment.
population_specificity: 75 women (25 per group) who underwent bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment involved percutaneous electrostimulation and specific training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of bariatric surgery, focusing on weight regain and the importance of lifelong follow-up to prevent poor outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that many bariatric surgery patients regain weight after 5 years, highlighting the need for lifelong follow-up to prevent poor outcomes, and provided a case study illustrating a poor outcome.
population_specificity: Postsurgical bariatric patients, particularly those with morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the impact of bariatric surgery on diabetic retinopathy (DR) progression compared to medical treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery reduced DR progression compared to medical treatment (OR, 0.47), but no significant difference was observed between patients with and without pre-existing DR. There was insufficient evidence to assess effects on DR regression.
population_specificity: 876 patients who underwent bariatric surgery, including those with and without diabetic retinopathy at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bariatric surgery with lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy in achieving weight loss and improving obesity-related comorbidities.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, particularly Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy, resulted in long-term weight reductions of ≥20% of initial weight, associated with decreased morbidity and potentially mortality. These outcomes were superior to lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy for patients with severe obesity.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity who were unable to achieve satisfactory weight loss with lifestyle intervention and pharmacotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and outcomes of bariatric surgery for severe obesity, including its impact on obesity-related comorbidities and quality of life.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be effective in improving and remitting obesity-related comorbidities, providing sustained weight loss, and enhancing quality of life. It also demonstrated superior outcomes for Type 2 diabetes mellitus compared to conventional medical therapy, though it carries unique short-term and long-term complications.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity, particularly those with obesity-related comorbidities like Type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize systematic reviews on the surgeon volume-outcome relationship, specifically examining its presence in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that high-quality reviews support a positive volume-outcome relationship in bariatric surgery, indicating better outcomes with higher surgeon volumes. The evidence was clear-cut, showing large effects for bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a Core Outcome Set (COS) for bariatric and metabolic surgery trials to standardize outcome reporting and improve data synthesis.
results_summary: The study identified nine key outcomes for inclusion in the COS, such as weight, diabetes status, cardiovascular risk, and quality of life, through systematic reviews, patient interviews, and Delphi surveys. The COS is recommended for use in all bariatric surgery trials to enhance research value and data comparability.
population_specificity: Patients and health professionals in the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolic markers associated with surgical and dietary treatments for weight loss in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery and dietary interventions led to metabolic adaptations resembling starvation ketoacidosis, increased fatty acid oxidation, and decreased specific amino acids and lipids linked to obesity. Bariatric surgery specifically increased bile acid levels, reduced ceramides, and improved glycemic control and inflammation.
population_specificity: Subjects with obesity undergoing surgical or dietary weight loss treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between liver disease severity and fat distribution in patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that younger patients stored fat more in subcutaneous tissue, delaying liver damage, while a shift to visceral fat storage was associated with liver disease severity. Female patients showed increased subcutaneous adipocyte volume correlating with liver disease progression.
population_specificity: 798 consecutive patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sleeve gastrectomy on liver steatosis using MRI and MRS as noninvasive methods.
results_summary: Six months after sleeve gastrectomy, a significant reduction in liver steatosis was observed, evidenced by decreased intrahepatocitary lipids and liver volume measured via MRS and MRI. These imaging techniques were validated as accurate for monitoring liver steatosis in bariatric surgery patients.
population_specificity: 23 patients (21 females, 2 males) with a mean age of 47.6 years and mean pre-op BMI of 47.6 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of whey protein supplementation on weight loss and body composition in women who regained weight 24 or more months after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: Whey protein supplementation, combined with a hypocaloric diet, promoted body weight and fat mass loss in women with long-term weight regain following RYGB. The study did not report significant adverse effects or detailed safety outcomes.
population_specificity: Women who regained at least 5% of their lowest postoperative weight after RYGB, with a mean age of 45 ± 11 years and BMI of 35.7 ± 5.2 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/kg of ideal body weight (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of IV iron compared to oral iron in various clinical situations, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that IV iron is superior to oral iron in efficacy and safety for iron-deficient patients, including those undergoing bariatric surgery, with minimal and self-limiting adverse events.
population_specificity: Iron-deficient patients, including those who underwent bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Total complete replacement doses in 1 or 2 sessions (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery (laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) compared to intensive lifestyle intervention and no treatment for managing NASH across different weight classes and fibrosis stages.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly increased QALYs (0.678-2.152) in obese patients (F0-F3) and was cost-effective for all obesity levels, while in overweight patients, it was cost-effective only for F3 fibrosis. Intensive lifestyle intervention also improved QALYs but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: Patients with NASH categorized by weight class (overweight, mild obesity, moderate obesity, severe obesity) and fibrosis stage (F0-F3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and clinical importance of leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and abnormal vital signs in patients undergoing laparoscopic gastric plication (LGP) during the postoperative period.
results_summary: Leukocytosis and neutrophilia were common after LGP (63% and 72%, respectively), compared to lower rates after cholecystectomy (38.5% and 18%). Minor complications occurred in 25% of LGP patients, with no mortality reported.
population_specificity: 44 consecutive LGP patients (mean BMI 37, mean age 42.5) and 44 laparoscopic cholecystectomy patients for comparison.

study_goal: To determine whether weight loss after bariatric surgery was associated with changes in periodontal measures over 12 months.
results_summary: Weight loss was associated with increased gingival bleeding, peaking at 6 months post-surgery, but periodontal pocketing and attachment loss remained unchanged. BMI loss correlated with higher bleeding on probing (BOP) but not with other periodontal outcomes.
population_specificity: 110 morbidly obese patients (BMI >40 kg/m²) from two public hospitals in São Paulo, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the long-term results (>5 years) of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) as a primary bariatric procedure, focusing on weight loss, co-morbidities, complications, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study analyzed 20 articles involving 2713 patients, with 1626 reaching ≥5-year follow-up. SG demonstrated significant weight loss (mean preoperative BMI 46.9 kg/m²) and addressed co-morbidities, though long-term complications and quality of life outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Predominantly female (71.3%) and male (28.7%) patients with severe obesity (mean BMI 46.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of obesity on lower limb biomechanics and total joint arthroplasty outcomes, as well as the role of bariatric surgery among patients requiring joint arthroplasty.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves gait biomechanics and, in severely obese patients with osteoarthritis, enhances pain and joint function. However, evidence supporting bariatric surgery before total joint arthroplasty is limited to retrospective reports with conflicting results.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients with osteoarthritis requiring joint arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between dietary protein or amino acid supplementation and postoperative outcomes after gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study found no convincing evidence of a beneficial effect of increased protein intake or amino acid supplementation on postoperative outcomes. The authors highlight the need for further research with clear descriptions of protein and amino acid composition.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing gastric bypass surgery for morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosage of vitamin B12 supplementation to correct deficiencies in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that 350 μg oral vitamin B12 is an appropriate dose to correct low vitamin B12 levels in many patients, though further research is needed on diagnosis, optimal dosing, and clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery with perioperative vitamin B12 deficiencies.
